name: 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The target compound, 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene, can be broken down into its basic unit, benzene, and its substituents. The benzene ring has a known melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The introduction of alkyl groups such as a methyl group and ethyl group generally leads to a decrease in melting point due to the increased molecular size creating a more complex shape that disrupts the crystal lattice less efficiently than the symmetric benzene ring. A methyl group typically reduces the melting point by about 5 degrees Celsius and an ethyl group might reduce it further by approximately 12 degrees Celsius because it's larger than a methyl group.

name: 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The target compound, 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene, is based on the benzene ring, which has a known melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Addition of alkyl groups such as a methyl and an ethyl group tends to lower the melting point of the compound. Each methyl group typically lowers the melting point by around 5 degrees Celsius due to its small size and induced dipole-dipole interactions that do not significantly disrupt the crystal lattice. However, the ethyl group, being larger than a methyl group, will have a more pronounced effect on lowering the melting point. The ethyl group can be estimated to lower the melting point by approximately 8 degrees Celsius as it disrupts the crystal lattice more than the methyl group due to its additional -CH2- unit. Therefore, the combined effect of one methyl and one ethyl group would be a decrease of 13 degrees Celsius from the base melting point of benzene.

name: 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. A methyl group usually lowers the melting point slightly due to a small increase in molecular weight and volume without significantly increasing intermolecular forces, approximately -5°C. An ethyl group has a similar effect to the methyl group but is slightly more bulky, which could have a slightly larger impact on lowering the melting point, approximately -10°C. Therefore, the combined effect of the methyl and ethyl groups could be an additional decrease in melting point.
Prediction: Base benzene melting point of 5.5°C - 5°C for the methyl group - 10°C for the ethyl group gives a predicted melting point of -9.5°C.

name: 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of a methyl group usually lowers the melting point by increasing the molecular weight and volume without a proportionate increase in intermolecular forces; this effect can be approximately -5°C. An ethyl group also decreases the melting point due to increased bulkiness, but typically has a greater effect than a methyl group, estimated at -10°C. However, the actual value of -81°C for 1-methyl-2-ethylbenzene suggests a much larger decrease than what is predicted by the addition of these alkyl groups. This discrepancy may indicate that other factors are at play, such as increased molecular asymmetry and resulting decreased packing efficiency, that are not accounted for in the simple additive effects of the substituents.
